question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run for the Republican nomination in the 2024 US Presidential Election. The primary field is predominantly led by other prominent figures, including his father, former President Donald Trump, who has a significant base of support within the party. Donald Trump Jr.'s public activities have primarily focused on political advocacy and supporting his father's campaigns rather than pursuing his own presidential ambitions. Additionally, there have been no credible reports or indications from credible sources suggesting that he is actively seeking the nomination. Given these factors, it is highly unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 election.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no public indications or credible reports suggesting that President Joe Biden is facing imminent health risks that could lead to his passing before Friday, July 26, 2024. President Biden, born on November 20, 1942, has been actively fulfilling his presidential duties, and there have been no official announcements or credible sources implying any serious health concerns that would result in his death within the specified timeframe. While it's impossible to predict such events with absolute certainty, the lack of any substantial information pointing towards this outcome suggests that it is highly unlikely.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Joe Biden is serving as the incumbent President of the United States. There have been no public announcements or credible indications suggesting that he intends to resign, pass away, or otherwise leave office before the end of July 2024. Additionally, assuming there are no unforeseen health issues or political upheavals, it is reasonable to expect that he will continue to serve as President through the specified period. Temporary transfers of power under the 25th Amendment do not qualify as resolutions for this question, and there is no ongoing situation that would likely trigger such a transfer. Therefore, the likelihood of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is high.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday or will he cease to be President before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if either (a) there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, or (b) Joe Biden resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be US President before the end of July 2024 (ET). Resolves NO if neither condition is met.

Note: Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of mid-2024, Joe Biden is the sitting President of the United States and was born on November 20, 1942, making him 81 years old. Statistically, the mortality rate for males in the United States aged 80-84 is approximately 10-15% over one year. However, individual health factors, access to medical care, and lifestyle can significantly influence this probability. Given Biden's access to top-tier healthcare and assuming no major unforeseen health issues, the likelihood of his passing before July 2024 is relatively low. Additionally, there is no public indication of him planning to resign or step down from the presidency voluntarily within this timeframe. Therefore, while there is a non-negligible risk associated with his age, the probability of either his death or cessation from the presidency before the end of July 2024 remains low.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, President Joe Biden is approaching the age of 82 and has faced significant challenges during his first term, including economic issues, foreign policy conflicts, and domestic political pressures. While there have been occasional hints and speculation about his potential retirement, Biden has not made any definitive public statements indicating his intention not to seek re-election. The Democratic Party may weigh the benefits of an incumbent running for a second term against the desire for new leadership, especially if Biden's approval ratings remain a concern. Additionally, internal party dynamics, fundraising capabilities, and the political landscape as the 2024 election approaches will heavily influence his decision. Given these factors and the uncertainty surrounding his personal considerations and political calculations, there is a moderate likelihood that Biden may choose to announce his decision not to seek re-election before the July 15, 2024 deadline.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been discussions and legal considerations regarding the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify individuals from holding federal office due to involvement in insurrection or rebellion. Donald Trump was acquitted in his second impeachment trial related to the January 6, 2021, events at the U.S. Capitol. For Trump to be officially removed or blocked from a primary election ballot under this section by July 15, 2024, several significant legal and political hurdles would need to be overcome:

1. Legal Proceedings: There would need to be a definitive legal judgment declaring that Trump's actions meet the criteria of engaging in insurrection or rebellion as defined by Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This would likely involve lengthy court battles, appeals, and substantial legal scrutiny.

2. State-Level Actions: Election laws are governed at the state level, so each state would have its own procedures and standards for removing a candidate from the ballot. Coordinating actions across multiple states would be complex and time-consuming.

3. Political Will and Public Opinion: There would need to be strong political motivation and public support for such actions. Given Trump's significant political base, achieving consensus on his removal could be challenging.

4. Precedent and Interpretation: Section 3 has rarely been invoked in modern times, leading to uncertainties about its application. Courts would play a crucial role in interpreting the amendment, and their decisions could vary, adding to the unpredictability.

Considering these factors, while it's legally possible, the combination of procedural complexities, potential legal defenses, and political dynamics makes the outcome uncertain.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump remains a dominant figure within the Republican Party and has a substantial base of dedicated supporters. He has publicly declared his intention to seek the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election and continues to hold significant influence over the party's direction. Early polls and delegate counts suggest that Trump is leading among Republican contenders. However, there are emerging challenges from other prominent Republicans, such as Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and former Vice President Mike Pence, who are gaining traction and support within different factions of the party. Additionally, Trump's polarizing nature could lead to strong opposition among certain delegates, potentially impacting his ability to secure a majority at the Republican National Convention. Factors such as campaign dynamics, primary election outcomes, and potential shifts in voter sentiment in the remaining months leading up to the convention will play crucial roles in determining the final nominee.

question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note that the question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This condition is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, irrespective of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Evaluating the two conditions:

(a) **Removal of Donald Trump from primary ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment**: This would require substantial legal and political action. As of October 2023, there have been discussions and attempts to challenge Trump's eligibility, but no definitive legal rulings or widespread political movements have successfully removed him from ballots in any state. Implementing such a measure would involve complex legal battles and significant political consensus, which are currently lacking.

(b) **Donald Trump becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election**: Trump remains a prominent figure within the Republican Party with a strong and loyal supporter base. While there are other potential candidates, Trump's influence and previous electoral success make it plausible for him to secure the nomination. The dynamics of primary elections can be unpredictable, but Trump's sustained prominence increases the likelihood of him being the nominee.

Given that condition (b) is more likely to occur based on current political dynamics, the probability that at least one of the two conditions resolves as "Yes" is high.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Historically, the United States has been a dominant force in the Olympic Games, frequently leading the medal counts in both gold and overall medals. In recent Olympics, the USA has often secured more gold medals than silver medals. For instance, in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, the USA won 39 gold and 41 silver medals. However, performance can vary based on the specific sports, emerging talents, and the competitive landscape of each Games. Considering the USA's strong investment in athletics and the depth of their athlete pool, it's reasonable to anticipate that they will likely secure more gold medals than silver in the Paris 2024 Olympics.

Probability: 0.55

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a strong track record of leading the Olympic Medal Tables, consistently securing the top position in recent Olympic Games due to their extensive investment in a wide range of sports and a deep pool of talented athletes. While other countries, such as China and the host nation France, have shown significant improvements and competitive performances, the breadth and depth of the US Olympic team across numerous disciplines typically provide them with a competitive edge. Additionally, the experience and preparation leading up to the Paris 2024 Olympics are likely to bolster their performance further. Considering these factors, it is probable that the USA will top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024.

question.title: Will either of the following occur at the Paris 2024 Olympics: (a) The USA wins more Gold than Silver medals, or (b) The USA tops the Olympic Medal Table?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if either of the following occurs: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, or (b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. For part (b), the medal table is calculated by ordering countries by the number of Gold Medals, then Silver Medals, and then Bronze Medals.

(a) **USA Winning More Gold than Silver Medals**: Historically, the USA has been strong in sports that typically yield more gold medals, such as athletics and swimming. In the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, the USA secured more gold medals than silver (39 gold vs. 41 silver). However, recent trends show a slight shift, with the USA occasionally having more silver than gold in specific Olympics due to increased competition and depth in their athlete roster.

(b) **USA Topping the Olympic Medal Table**: The USA has consistently ranked in the top three in the medal table in recent Summer Olympics, often competing closely with countries like China and Japan. Factors such as investment in sports programs, athlete preparation, and emerging competitors will influence their ranking. Given the USA's strong sports infrastructure and talent pool, it's likely they will remain near the top.

Considering the overlapping nature of these scenarios—where the USA topping the medal table often correlates with having more gold medals—the probability that at least one of these conditions will be met is high.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in April 2023, there have been discussions and legal considerations regarding the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Donald Trump from holding federal office due to his actions surrounding the January 6th Capitol riot. However, no official actions, court rulings, or state-level decisions have been made to remove or block him from any primary election ballots under this provision. The process to enforce Section 3 involves complex legal challenges, including proving involvement in insurrection or rebellion, which requires substantial evidence and likely lengthy judicial proceedings. Additionally, political factors and potential pushback could influence the feasibility of such actions. Given these complexities and the time required to navigate the legal and political landscape, it is uncertain whether these efforts will culminate in Trump's removal or blocking from a primary ballot by July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Democratic Party in both the House and Senate consists of a substantial number of members, with the House having 220 Democrats and the Senate having around 50. Organizing a public letter opposing an early virtual nomination plan would require coordination, but the fact that Rep. Jared Huffman is already involved in drafting and circulating such a letter suggests there is momentum. Additionally, internal disagreements within parties, while not uncommon, often see multiple members voicing dissent to ensure diverse viewpoints are represented. Given that 20 signatories represent a relatively small fraction of the total Democratic caucus, and considering the ongoing efforts to articulate opposition, it is likely that at least 20 members will come forward to sign the letter by the specified deadline.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, OpenAI's ChatGPT is widely available internationally, including in the European Union. OpenAI has been proactive in addressing regulatory requirements such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) to ensure compliance within the EU. Additionally, there have been no significant announcements or indications suggesting that OpenAI plans to restrict access to ChatGPT in the EU by June 30, 2024. Given the importance of the EU market and OpenAI's commitment to accessibility, it is highly likely that ChatGPT will remain generally available in the European Union on the specified date.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the information provided, four Democratic House members have already publicly urged President Biden to end his re-election campaign. Additionally, there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, indicating active efforts to consolidate such pressure. The presence of safe-seat members and those who are already endangered suggests they have both the motivation and the platform to influence the decision. Given these factors, it is likely that a fifth named Democratic member will join this collective effort before the July 20th deadline.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

Additionally, internal party dynamics and support structures typically work to maintain unity during election cycles. Given the lack of evidence pointing towards such a development, it is unlikely that 10 or more Democratic Senators will call for Biden to step down before July 20.

As of October 2023, prominent potential candidates such as Kamala Harris, Gavin Newsom, Gretchen Whitmer, and incumbent President Joe Biden are likely to seek the Democratic nomination for the 2024 elections. The presence of these candidates increases the necessity for debates to facilitate meaningful competition and informed decision-making among voters. Considering these factors, it is highly probable that there will be another Democratic party presidential debate prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024 (b) There is another Democratic party presidential debate before the 2024 Democratic National Convention?
question.body:
(a) Will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024? Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html. If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

(b) Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate? Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g. Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Analyzing the two scenarios:

(a) **10 or more Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024**: Historically, it's uncommon for a significant number of members from the same party to publicly call for their own leader to step down without substantial reasons, such as major policy disagreements or scandals. As of the latest information up to October 2023, there haven't been indications of widespread dissatisfaction within the Democratic Senate caucus regarding President Biden's leadership. Additionally, internal party dynamics and the upcoming election would incentivize Senators to support the incumbent to maintain unity and improve re-election prospects.

(b) **Another Democratic party presidential debate before the 2024 Democratic National Convention**: It's standard for major political parties in the U.S., including the Democrats, to hold multiple debates during the primary season to determine their nominee. Given the competitive nature of presidential primaries and the presence of several potential candidates, it's highly likely that the Democratic Party will organize additional debates leading up to the National Convention to allow candidates to present their platforms and vie for support.

Considering these points, while scenario (a) is highly unlikely, scenario (b) is almost certain to occur.

question.title: Will Ireland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ireland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Ireland does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Ireland has a strong historical presence in the Eurovision Song Contest, having won the competition seven times, which is the most of any country. However, in recent years, Ireland has faced challenges in securing a spot in the Grand Final, with their qualification depending on various factors including the quality of their selected entry, the competition in their semi-final, and voting dynamics. The selection process for Eurovision entries typically involves national competitions or internal selections by the broadcaster, RTÉ in Ireland's case. The success of Ireland's entry will largely depend on the song's appeal, performance, and how it resonates with both the jury and the public across Europe. Additionally, geopolitical factors and bloc voting can influence the outcomes, although the European Broadcasting Union has measures in place to mitigate overt biases. Given these variables and without specific information on the 2024 entry, it's challenging to predict with high certainty.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

metadata.chain_of_thought: The projected opening weekend gross for "Deadpool x Wolverine" is between $340 million and $360 million globally, significantly surpassing the previous R-rated movie record of $284.5 million. Additionally, the domestic projection of $160 million to $170 million exceeds the original Deadpool's $152.2 million domestic opening. The strong fan base for both Deadpool and Wolverine, combined with the expanded theater release, supports these optimistic forecasts. However, uncertainties such as competition from other releases, potential market saturation, and the reliance on projections rather than confirmed reports introduce some risk. Given these factors, there is a high likelihood that the movie will achieve the projected numbers and set a new R-rated opening weekend record, pending confirmation from reliable sources like the Hollywood Reporter.

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Vivek Ramaswamy has emerged as one of the contenders in the Republican primary for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While he brings a fresh perspective and appeals to certain segments of the Republican base, the nomination landscape is heavily influenced by established figures like former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who have significant name recognition, established fundraising networks, and substantial support within the party. Additionally, the Republican National Convention delegates tend to favor candidates with proven track records and strong grassroots support. Unless Ramaswamy can significantly increase his visibility, secure key endorsements, and outperform the leading candidates in upcoming primaries and caucuses, his chances of securing the nomination remain uncertain. Given these factors, it is somewhat unlikely but not impossible that Vivek Ramaswamy will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump has already been indicted in Georgia on multiple charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election results, including conspiracy and obstruction of justice. However, witness tampering has not been among the charges brought against him to date. While ongoing investigations could potentially lead to additional charges, there has been no public indication or evidence suggesting that witness tampering specifically is being considered. Given the absence of such charges so far and the lack of information pointing towards future charges in this area, it is unlikely that Trump will be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024.

question.title: Will either Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention) and is not affected by who receives the nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. (b) Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that either Vivek Ramaswamy becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or Donald Trump is charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024, we consider both scenarios independently and then account for any overlap. 1. **Vivek Ramaswamy as Republican Nominee:** As of October 2023, Vivek Ramaswamy has entered the Republican primary race. While he brings fresh perspectives, the Republican base has shown strong support for established figures like Donald Trump. Historically, incumbent or prominent candidates have a higher likelihood of securing the nomination. Given these factors, there's a moderate probability of Ramaswamy securing the nomination, but significant competition makes this uncertain. 2. **Donald Trump Charged with Witness Tampering:** Donald Trump has faced multiple legal challenges across various jurisdictions. While witness tampering is a serious charge, the likelihood of such a specific charge being filed by June 1, 2024, depends on ongoing investigations and legal proceedings. Given the timeline and the nature of legal processes, there's a notable but uncertain probability of this occurring. Assuming independence between these two events, the combined probability is calculated as: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A) × P(B) Estimating P(A) as 0.25 and P(B) as 0.25: P(A or B) = 0.25 + 0.25 - (0.25 × 0.25) = 0.4375 Taking into account potential dependencies and uncertainties, a rounded probability provides a more conservative estimate.

question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, tensions between Israel and Iran have been historically high, with both nations engaging in proxy conflicts and cyber operations. However, carrying out a deadly attack within Iran itself would entail significant risks, including potential retaliation against Israeli interests and civilian populations, escalation into broader regional conflict, and international diplomatic repercussions. Additionally, such an action would likely require substantial intelligence and logistical planning. Given these factors, while the possibility cannot be entirely dismissed due to the adversarial relationship, the likelihood of Israel executing a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024, remains relatively low.

Considering the complexities and the lack of compelling evidence pointing towards either event occurring by May 1, 2024, it is unlikely that either scenario will unfold within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Chasiv Yar is a strategic town in the Donetsk region of Ukraine that has been a focal point in the ongoing conflict between Russian and Ukrainian forces. The town holds significant logistical importance due to its rail connections and proximity to other contested areas. Throughout 2023, there have been fluctuating control dynamics, with both Russian and Ukrainian forces making advances and experiencing setbacks in the region. While Russia has demonstrated substantial military capabilities and has been intent on expanding its control over key territories in Ukraine, several factors could influence the outcome by June 1, 2024. These include the resilience and tactical effectiveness of Ukrainian defense efforts, potential shifts in international support for Ukraine, the availability of military resources, and the broader geopolitical landscape. Additionally, logistical challenges, potential sanctions, and internal dynamics within the Russian military could impact their ability to sustain and consolidate control over Chasiv Yar. Considering the complexity and unpredictability of the conflict, it is challenging to assign a high probability to Russia maintaining control by the specified date.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Joe Biden, as the incumbent president, traditionally there is a strong tendency for sitting presidents to seek re-election. However, several factors might influence his decision not to run. Biden's age is a significant consideration; born in 1942, he would be approaching 82 by the 2024 election. Health concerns and the physical and mental demands of another presidential campaign could play a role in his decision-making process. Additionally, the political climate, including his administration's approval ratings and party support, might affect his willingness to pursue a second term. As of October 2023, Biden has not made a definitive public statement regarding his intention to run for re-election. While there is speculation and pressure from certain factions within the Democratic Party for him to consider stepping aside, the tradition and perceived advantages of incumbency generally support the likelihood of him seeking renomination unless compelling reasons arise to deter him. Balancing these factors, the probability that Biden will announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President is moderate but leans towards the likelihood that he will seek re-election.

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that the Republican Party will retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, several factors need to be considered: 1. Historical Voting Patterns: Ohio's 6th district has traditionally leaned Republican. If the district has consistently voted for Republican candidates in previous elections, this trend may continue unless significant demographic or political shifts occur. 2. Incumbency Advantage: If the Republican candidate has incumbency advantage, such as existing name recognition and established support networks, this can favor retention. However, since it's a special election and the seat was previously held by Bill Johnson, the impact depends on whether the new candidate has similar advantages. 3. Candidate Strength: The popularity, campaign effectiveness, and public perception of the Republican candidate versus their Democratic opponent will significantly influence the election outcome. A strong Republican candidate with broad support can increase the likelihood of retaining the seat. 4. National Political Climate: National trends and the performance of the Republican Party at the federal level can impact local elections. If the party is experiencing high approval ratings and successful legislative achievements, it may boost the chances of Republican candidates in local races. 5. Local Issues: Specific local concerns, such as economic conditions, infrastructure projects, or social issues unique to Ohio's 6th district, can sway voter preferences. If the Republican Party effectively addresses these issues, it can aid in retaining the seat. 6. Voter Turnout: Special elections often have lower voter turnout, which can favor parties with highly motivated voter bases. If Republican voters are more mobilized, this could enhance their retention prospects. Considering these factors, if there are no significant shifts in voter sentiment, the Republican candidate maintains strong local support, and the national climate favors Republicans, the probability of retaining the seat remains relatively high.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the likelihood of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, several factors must be considered:

1. **Legal Grounds**: Section 3 of the 14th Amendment prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or given aid or comfort to its enemies, from holding federal office. Applying this to Trump would require a legal determination that his actions meet this criterion.

2. **Evidence and Proceedings**: As of October 2023, there have been investigations and discussions regarding Trump's involvement in events like the January 6th Capitol riot. However, establishing a legal case strong enough to meet the standards of Section 3 requires substantial evidence and due process, including potential court rulings.

3. **Political Landscape**: Removing a major political figure from ballot access is unprecedented and would likely involve significant political contention. The decision would not only be a legal matter but also a highly politicized one, affecting multiple states and jurisdictions with varying laws and processes.

4. **State-Level Actions**: Since ballot access laws are determined at the state level, it would require multiple states to independently decide to block Trump from ballots, each navigating their own legal challenges. The coordination and consensus needed across multiple states make this a complex endeavor.

5. **Precedent and Historical Context**: There is limited precedent for removing a major contender from ballots under the 14th Amendment. The lack of historical examples suggests that such an action would be unprecedented and face numerous legal hurdles.

6. **Timeline**: Considering the resolution date is July 15, 2024, the timeframe for mounting such legal challenges, conducting thorough investigations, and achieving the necessary legal and political consensus is relatively short, adding to the improbability.

Taking all these factors into account, while it is not impossible, the combination of legal complexities, the need for substantial evidence, political challenges, and the tight timeline makes the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from any primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the specified date relatively low.

question.title: Will either Biden remain President through the end of July 2024 or Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following occurs:

(a) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). This resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution).

(b) On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The primary condition for the question to resolve as "Yes" is that either Joe Biden remains President through the end of July 2024 or Donald Trump is removed from the primary election ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. Considering the current political landscape, it is highly probable that Joe Biden will remain President through July 2024, provided there are no unforeseen circumstances such as resignation, incapacitation, or removal through the 25th Amendment. Historically, such events are rare and there is no current indication suggesting that they are likely in Biden's case. On the other hand, the removal of Donald Trump from primary ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment would require significant legal and political actions, which are highly improbable given the complexities and precedents involved. Therefore, the likelihood that at least one of these conditions is met by July 2024 is extremely high.

question.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The European Union (EU) has been actively working towards enhancing its automotive industry, particularly in the electric vehicle (EV) sector, to meet its climate and sustainability goals. China is a major player in the global EV market, both in production and innovation. While the EU aims to foster local EV manufacturing, imposing new tariffs on Chinese imports could lead to trade tensions and retaliatory measures, which the EU typically seeks to avoid to maintain smooth international relations. Additionally, the EU often prefers negotiation and collaboration over protectionist measures unless there are significant concerns about unfair trade practices or safety standards. Given these factors, while there is some motivation for the EU to protect its domestic EV industry, the likelihood of announcing new tariffs or duties specifically targeting Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024, appears low.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The situation involves internal pressure within the Democratic Party for President Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign. According to reports, two safe-seat members and two of the most endangered Democrats have already publicly urged Biden to drop out. Additionally, there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats aiming to collectively ask Biden to end his campaign. However, the market specifically requires that at least five named Democratic House Members or Senators work together in a unified group message to meet the criteria for a "YES" resolution. Forming such a group publicly would require significant coordination and consensus within the party, which can be challenging given the potential political ramifications. While there is clear internal pressure, transitioning that into a formal, public group action by at least five named individuals before July 20th may be difficult due to political strategy considerations and the potential impact on the party’s unity and public image. Therefore, while the indicators point towards increased pressure, the likelihood of the specific criteria being met is relatively low.

question.title: Will either the EU announce tariffs on Chinese EVs by July 5, 2024, or at least 5 Dem House Members/Senators urge Biden to drop out by July 20, 2024?
question.body:

(a) Before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced new tariffs or duties that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

(b) Before July 20, 2024 (Pacific Time), a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members or US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so. This could be by signing a letter or another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out. All five individuals must be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient. Reports of unnamed Democrats asking Biden to step aside will not satisfy the criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are made public before the end date. In ambiguous cases, the resolution will err towards NO unless confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that either the EU announces tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) by July 5, 2024, or that at least five Democratic House Members or Senators urge President Joe Biden to drop out by July 20, 2024, we can evaluate both scenarios separately:

**Scenario (a): EU Tariffs on Chinese EVs**
- **Current Trade Relations**: As of late 2023, the EU and China have been negotiating various trade agreements, including those related to the automotive sector. Introducing tariffs would likely escalate trade tensions.
- **Market Factors**: The EU aims to promote its own EV industry and reduce reliance on non-EU manufacturers. However, imposing tariffs could lead to retaliatory measures from China, affecting other sectors.
- **Political Climate**: There is no strong indication of imminent protectionist measures targeting Chinese EVs specifically by the EU within the given timeframe.

**Scenario (b): Democratic Lawmakers Urging Biden to Drop Out**
- **Party Unity**: Historically, the Democratic Party has shown relative unity in supporting its presidential candidates. Publicly urging a sitting president to drop out would represent a significant rift.
- **Biden's Standing**: President Biden, as of mid-2024, has maintained a stable approval rating, and there is no widespread movement within the party to challenge his candidacy aggressively.
- **Political Strategy**: It is uncommon for multiple members of the same party to publicly call for the withdrawal of their own leader without substantial cause.

Given the analysis of both scenarios, neither appears highly likely to occur within the specified timeframes.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Liz Cheney is a prominent Republican figure known for her outspoken criticism of former President Donald Trump and her role in the events surrounding the 2020 election certification. Her stance has positioned her at odds with a significant portion of the Republican base, which remains largely supportive of Trump. In the 2022 midterm elections, Cheney lost her primary to a Trump-endorsed challenger, highlighting the challenges she faces within the party. Given the current dynamics of the Republican Party, where alignment with Trump continues to be a dominant factor, it is unlikely that Cheney will secure the necessary support at the Republican National Convention to become the party's nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Ohio's 6th congressional district has historically leaned Republican, with Bill Johnson previously holding the seat. Given the district's partisan alignment and assuming no major political shifts or unexpected events occur before the 2024 special election, it is likely that the Republican Party will retain the seat. Additionally, special elections can sometimes have lower turnout, which may benefit the incumbent party if their base is more motivated to vote. Without significant Democratic momentum or a particularly strong Democratic candidate emerging, the probability favors a Republican hold.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (1) Liz Cheney becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, or (2) The Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (1) Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the nomination on the day of the election. (2) A person representing the Republican Party wins the special election for Ohio's 6th congressional district. Credible sources must report this outcome, and if there is disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, this part of the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the probability that either Liz Cheney becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or the Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, we need to evaluate both scenarios independently and then consider their combined likelihood.

1. **Liz Cheney as the Republican Nominee:**
   - **Current Standing:** As of October 2023, Liz Cheney is a prominent Republican figure known for her conservative stance and criticism of former President Donald Trump. However, her vocal opposition to Trump has limited her support within the broader Republican base, which remains influential in determining the party's nominee.
   - **Primary Dynamics:** The Republican primaries have numerous contenders, many of whom have strong backing from key party factions. Cheney would need to secure significant support from delegates, which is challenging given the current political climate and her position relative to other candidates.
   - **Historical Context:** Historically, incumbents or candidates with strong establishment support have an advantage in securing nominations. Cheney's stance, while principled, may not align with the majority preference within the party base.

2. **Retention of Ohio's 6th Congressional District:**
   - **Historical Voting Patterns:** Ohio's 6th congressional district has leaned Republican in recent elections. If the district continues to exhibit strong Republican support, the party is likely to retain the seat.
   - **Candidate Strength:** The outcome will also depend on the strength and campaign effectiveness of both the Republican and Democratic candidates. Incumbency and local issues will play significant roles.
   - **Political Climate:** National trends can influence local elections. If the Republican Party maintains its cohesion and voter turnout in Ohio remains consistent, retention is plausible.

**Combined Assessment:**
While Liz Cheney becoming the Republican nominee appears unlikely given the current dynamics within the party, the Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district seems more probable based on historical trends and current political factors.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has not made any public indications that he intends to forgo seeking a second term in the 2024 election. Historically, incumbent presidents often announce their re-election bids well in advance to solidify their campaigns and fundraising efforts. Biden was elected in 2020 and has been actively involved in his administration's initiatives, suggesting a commitment to his role. Additionally, there haven't been significant indicators, such as major health concerns or unprecedented political pressures, that would strongly suggest he might choose not to run. Given the typical behavior of incumbent presidents and the lack of concrete signs pointing toward his withdrawal, it is unlikely that Biden will announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: I'm unable to provide a probability estimate for whether FiveThirtyEight will project Joe Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024, as this date is beyond my knowledge cutoff in October 2023.

question.title: Will Poland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Larry Elder has not formally announced a campaign for the Republican nomination in the 2024 US Presidential Election. The Republican field is expected to be highly competitive, with several prominent candidates likely to vie for the nomination, including names like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, among others. Larry Elder, while a recognized conservative commentator and having run for public office in the past, may face challenges in gaining the necessary support and visibility compared to more established or widely recognized candidates. Additionally, the dynamics of the Republican National Convention often favor candidates with broader grassroots support and stronger fundraising capabilities. Unless there are significant shifts in the political landscape or Elder makes a substantial strategic move, it is unlikely that he will secure the nomination.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Kamala Harris be the Democratic VP nominee, or (b) Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic VP. If someone else is selected as VP, this market will resolve to no. If the VP is changed for any reason after the initial nomination, that will not change the resolution of this market. The market can resolve immediately after the nomination.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question asks whether either (a) Kamala Harris will be the Democratic VP nominee or (b) Larry Elder will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. 

(a) **Kamala Harris as Democratic VP Nominee**: As the current Vice President under President Joe Biden, Kamala Harris is the presumptive Democratic VP nominee for the 2024 election. Historically, incumbent vice presidents are highly likely to be re-nominated unless there is a significant political shift or personal decision to step down. There have been no indications of such changes, making this outcome very probable.

(b) **Larry Elder as Republican Presidential Nominee**: Larry Elder is a conservative commentator and has expressed interest in running for office. However, the Republican field often includes established figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and others who have significant support within the party. While Elder has a presence, the likelihood of him securing the Republican nomination against more prominent candidates is relatively low.

Assuming the two events are independent, the probability that either (a) or (b) occurs is calculated as:
\[ P(a \text{ or } b) = P(a) + P(b) - P(a) \times P(b) \]

Given:
- \( P(a) \) is approximately 0.95 (95% chance Kamala Harris is the Democratic VP nominee)
- \( P(b) \) is approximately 0.05 (5% chance Larry Elder is the Republican nominee)

Calculating:
\[ P(a \text{ or } b) = 0.95 + 0.05 - (0.95 \times 0.05) = 0.95 + 0.05 - 0.0475 = 0.9525 \]

Therefore, the combined probability is approximately 0.95.

question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if either of the following conditions is met: (a) The athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in the swimming events. (b) The same National Olympic Committee (NOC) wins gold in more than one of the eight women's team sports: association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. metadata.chain_of_thought: At the 2024 Paris Olympics, swimmers typically have the potential to accumulate multiple gold medals due to the high number of events they participate in. However, the landscape of Olympic competition has become increasingly competitive with athletes specializing more, which may limit the number of medals a single swimmer can amass compared to past Olympics. On the other hand, examining the eight women's team sports—association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo—strong National Olympic Committees (NOCs) like the United States, which traditionally excels in multiple team sports such as basketball and volleyball, are likely to secure gold in more than one of these disciplines. Given the historical performance and the distribution of strengths across NOCs in these team sports, it is highly probable that a single NOC will win gold in multiple women's team events, thereby satisfying condition (b). Even if condition (a) is less certain due to increasing competition among swimmers, the high likelihood of condition (b) being met ensures that the overall question will resolve as **Yes**.
